newsitem.title: INDIA: Arafat to put Mideast peace on non-aligned agenda.
newsitem.headline: Arafat to put Mideast peace on non-aligned agenda.

text.p: Palestinian President Yasser Arafat was to arrive in India on Sunday for a meeting of the Non-Aligned Movement (NAM), thrusting the Middle East peace process to the top of the conference's agenda, officials said.

Arafat was expected to arrive in the Indian capital late on Sunday and address a special plenary session of NAM foreign ministers meeting on Monday morning, Palestinian ambassador to India Khalid el-Sheikh told Reuters.

The conference's secretary-general, Savitri Kunnadi, said the movement was considering adopting a special declaration on the Palestinian issue after Arafat's speech. The Palestinians hold the vice presidency of the 113-member NAM.

A draft of the meeting's conclusions said the movement's members "reaffirmed their full support for the legitimate struggle of the Palestinian people to secure their inalienable rights to self-determination and independence and reiterated their demand for the withdrawal of Israel from all occupied Palestinian and other Arab lands, including Jerusalem".
The draft, obtained by Reuters, was expected to be finalised and adopted by NAM ministers on Tuesday.

The Palestinian ambassador to India said senior officials of NAM member-states on Saturday approved a draft resolution calling for a special session of the United Nations General Assembly on the Palestinian issue.

Arafat's surprise visit to New Delhi was expected to dominate the first day of the NAM meeting and push the stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace process to the top of its agenda, which will otherwise focus on U.N. reform and disarmament.
Middle East peace talks were halted after Israel began work last month on a new Jewish settlement in Arab East Jerusalem, sparking daily clashes between Palestinians and Israeli troops.
On Saturday, Palestinian officials warned of a "comprehensive explosion" which could lead to more confrontations and said they were sending a message to U.S. President Bill Clinton.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was scheduled to meet Clinton on Monday.
Arafat was to meet Indian President Shankar Dayal Sharma, Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda and Foreign Minister Inder Kumar Gujral on Monday.
